Chevalier de Saint-Georges
==========================

Joseph Bologne Chevalier de Saint-Georges (1748-1799) was a French composer, conductor, and violinist of African descent, who was active in Paris during the late 18th century. He was one of the most accomplished musicians of his time, known for his technical skill, musicality, and innovative compositions. Saint-Georges' life was marked by his struggles against racism and his efforts to gain recognition as a musician, despite the societal norms of his time.

Early life
-----------

Joseph Bologne was born on December 25, 1748, on the island of Guadeloupe, to a wealthy plantation owner, Georges de Bologne Saint-Georges, and his African slave, Nanon. His father, who was also a musician, recognized his son's musical talent at an early age and provided him with musical training. In 1753, Saint-Georges' father moved the family to Paris, where he continued his son's musical education.

Musical life and career
----------------------

Saint-Georges began his musical career as a violinist, performing in various orchestras and chamber music ensembles in Paris. He quickly gained recognition for his technical skill and musicality, and by the late 1760s, he was considered one of the most accomplished violinists in Paris. In 1769, he was appointed as the conductor of the Concert des Amateurs, a prominent concert society in Paris.

Operas
--------

Saint-Georges composed several operas, including "Ernestine" (1777), "La Partie de Chasse" (1778), and "L'Amant anonyme" (1780). His operas were known for their innovative use of orchestration and their blend of French and Italian musical styles.

Social life in Paris
--------------------

Saint-Georges was a prominent figure in Parisian society, known for his charming personality and his musical talent. He was a frequent guest at the salons of prominent aristocrats and intellectuals, where he would perform and socialize with the cream of Parisian society.

St. Georges assaulted
--------------------

Despite his success and popularity, Saint-Georges faced racism and prejudice throughout his life. In 1787, he was assaulted by a group of men who were jealous of his success and resentful of his African heritage. The incident was widely reported in the press, and it marked a turning point in Saint-Georges' life, as he became increasingly aware of the societal norms and expectations that sought to limit his opportunities.

Two trips to London
-------------------

In 1785, Saint-Georges traveled to London, where he performed as a violinist and composer. He was well-received by the London music scene, and his music was praised by critics and audiences alike.

Second trip
------------

In 1787, Saint-Georges returned to London, where he composed several works, including his famous "Symphonie concertante" for two violins. The work was premiered at the Haymarket Theatre in London, and it was a major success.

Lille
------

In 1791, Saint-Georges traveled to Lille, where he was appointed as the director of the local opera company. He stayed in Lille for several years, composing music and conducting performances.

Military career
----------------

During the French Revolution, Saint-Georges joined the military, where he served as a lieutenant colonel in the Légion St-Georges, a regiment composed of soldiers of African descent. He fought in several battles, including the Battle of Valmy, and he was wounded in combat.

Possible Saint-Domingue visit
-----------------------------

There is evidence to suggest that Saint-Georges may have visited Saint-Domingue (present-day Haiti) in the late 1790s, although the exact nature and purpose of his visit are unclear.

Death
------

Saint-Georges died on June 10, 1799, in Paris, at the age of 50. His death was likely due to complications from his war injuries.

Home
-----

Saint-Georges' home in Paris, located at 3, rue de la Tour-des-Dames, is now a museum dedicated to his life and work.

article:
Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves
=====================================

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves is a 2023 American fantasy adventure film directed by Jonathan Goldstein and John Francis Daley, based on the popular tabletop role-playing game Dungeons & Dragons. The film marks the first major motion picture adaptation of the game since the 2000 film Dungeons & Dragons.

Plot
-----

The film follows a group of thieves and adventurers, including Edgin (Chris Pine), Holga (Michelle Rodriguez), and Simon (Justice Smith), as they embark on a perilous quest to retrieve a powerful artifact. Along the way, they must navigate treacherous landscapes, battle fearsome enemies, and confront their own personal demons.

As the story unfolds, the group discovers that the artifact they seek is more than just a simple treasure – it holds the key to unlocking the secrets of their past and the fate of their world. With the help of a mysterious sorceress, Sofina (Chloe Coleman), the group must use all their skills and cunning to overcome the challenges ahead and emerge victorious.

Cast
-----

* Chris Pine as Edgin, a charismatic thief and leader of the group
* Michelle Rodriguez as Holga, a tough and skilled warrior
* Justice Smith as Simon, a charming and resourceful rogue
* Regé-Jean Page as Xenk, a cunning and deadly fighter
* Hugh Grant as Forge, a powerful wizard
* Chloe Coleman as Sofina, a mysterious and powerful sorceress
* Sophia Lillis as Doric, a young and talented wizard

Production
------------

### Development and casting

In 2016, Paramount Pictures announced plans to develop a new Dungeons & Dragons film, with Jonathan Goldstein and John Francis Daley set to direct. The project was initially intended to be a more serious, darker take on the game, but the filmmakers eventually shifted towards a more lighthearted, comedic approach.

Casting for the film began in 2020, with Chris Pine and Michelle Rodriguez among the first actors to join the project. The cast was rounded out over the next year, with Regé-Jean Page, Justice Smith, and Sophia Lillis joining the ensemble.

### Writing

The screenplay for the film was written by Goldstein and Daley, along with Michael Gilio. The script drew heavily from the game's source material, incorporating elements of the game's world, characters, and mythology.

The writers aimed to create a story that would appeal to both longtime fans of the game and newcomers alike, balancing action, adventure, and humor with heartfelt character moments.

### Filming and visual effects

Principal photography for the film began in April 2021, with filming taking place in the United Kingdom and Iceland. The production team made use of a combination of practical and visual effects to bring the game's fantastical world to life.

The film's visual effects were handled by a team of artists and technicians from companies such as ILM and MPC. The effects included the creation of elaborate environments, creatures, and action sequences, as well as the design and animation of the film's magical effects.

Music
------

The score for the film was composed by Lorne Balfe, who incorporated elements of fantasy and adventure music into his work. The soundtrack also featured a number of original songs, including a title track performed by the band Panic! At The Disco.

Release
--------

### Theatrical

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves was released in theaters on March 31, 2023, in the United States and the United Kingdom. The film received a wide release, playing on over 4,000 screens in the US alone.

### Home media

The film was released on digital platforms in May 2023, followed by a physical release on Blu-ray and DVD in June 2023.

Marketing
-----------

### Promotion

The marketing campaign for the film began in earnest in 2022, with the release of a series of trailers and TV spots. The campaign focused on highlighting the film's action, adventure, and humor, as well as its connections to the game.

The film's cast and crew also made the rounds on the promotional circuit, appearing on talk shows and at fan events to promote the film.

### Tie-in literature and merchandise

A number of tie-in books and other merchandise were released in conjunction with the film, including a novelization of the screenplay and a series of comic books and video games.

Reception
----------

### Box office

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves performed well at the box office, grossing over $200 million worldwide in its opening weekend. The film went on to gross over $500 million worldwide, making it a commercial success.

### Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising its action, adventure, and humor. The film holds a 74% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on over 200 reviews.

### Accolades

The film received a number of awards and nominations, including a nomination for Best Visual Effects at the 2024 Academy Awards.

Future
---------

### Possible sequel

In the months following the film's release, there was speculation about the possibility of a sequel. In an interview with Entertainment Weekly, the film's directors expressed interest in returning to the world of Dungeons & Dragons for another adventure.

### Spin-off television series

In 2023, it was announced that a spin-off television series based on the film was in development, with Goldstein and Daley set to executive produce. The series is expected to premiere on Paramount+ in 2024.

Notes
------

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves marks the first major motion picture adaptation of the game since the 2000 film Dungeons & Dragons.

The film's script was written by Jonathan Goldstein and John Francis Daley, along with Michael Gilio.

The film's score was composed by Lorne Balfe, who incorporated elements of fantasy and adventure music into his work.

2021–22 Premier League

The 2021–22 Premier League was the 30th season of the Premier League, the top English professional league for association football clubs, since its establishment in 1992. The season started on 13 August 2021 and concluded on 22 May 2022.

# Summary

The 2021–22 Premier League season was marked by several key events that shaped the campaign.

## The race for first place

The title race was highly competitive, with Manchester City and Liverpool emerging as the top two contenders. Manchester City, led by manager Pep Guardiola, were seeking to win their fourth title in five years, while Liverpool, under Jürgen Klopp, were looking to claim their second title in three years. The two teams were neck and neck for much of the season, with Manchester City eventually edging out Liverpool by a single point.

## Newcastle takeover

In October 2021, Newcastle United was taken over by a consortium backed by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund. The takeover led to a significant increase in the club's financial resources, and they were able to make several high-profile signings in the January transfer window.

## COVID-19 outbreaks force postponements

The season was disrupted by several COVID-19 outbreaks, which led to the postponement of numerous matches. The outbreaks were particularly severe in December 2021, with several teams experiencing significant numbers of positive cases.

## Abramovich sanctions

In March 2022, Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich was sanctioned by the UK government due to his alleged ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin. The sanctions had a significant impact on Chelsea, who were forced to operate under a special license that restricted their ability to sign new players or sell tickets.

## Final day climax

The final day of the season was marked by a dramatic climax, as Manchester City came from behind to defeat Aston Villa 3-2 and win the title. Liverpool, who had been leading the league for much of the day, ultimately finished one point behind Manchester City.

### Title

Manchester City won the title with 93 points, one point ahead of Liverpool.

### Relegation

The three teams that were relegated to the EFL Championship were Norwich City, Watford, and Everton.

### Champions League, Europa League and Conference League spots

The top four teams in the league qualified for the Champions League, while the fifth and sixth-placed teams qualified for the Europa League. The seventh-placed team, West Ham United, qualified for the Europa Conference League.

## Other teams

Several other teams had notable seasons, including Chelsea, who finished third despite the challenges posed by the Abramovich sanctions. Tottenham Hotspur finished fourth, while Arsenal finished fifth. Manchester United finished sixth, but qualified for the Europa League due to their victory in the UEFA Europa League.

article:
2023 Gabonese Coup d'état

The 2023 Gabonese coup d'état was a military coup that took place in Gabon on August 30, 2023, when a group of military officers overthrew the government of President Ali Bongo Ondimba. The coup marked the end of Bongo's 14-year rule and led to the establishment of a new government in the country.

# Background

Gabon, a small country located in Central Africa, had been ruled by the Bongo family for over five decades. Omar Bongo Ondimba, Ali's father, had been president of the country from 1967 until his death in 2009. Ali Bongo Ondimba succeeded his father as president and had been in power since 2009.

## 2023 Elections

In 2023, Gabon was scheduled to hold presidential elections, which were seen as a test of Bongo's popularity. However, the elections were marred by controversy and opposition claims of irregularities. Bongo's main challenger, Jean Ping, a former African Union Commission chairman, had been a vocal critic of the government and had accused Bongo of rigging the elections. The elections were held on August 26, 2023, and Bongo was declared the winner by the electoral commission. However, Ping and other opposition candidates disputed the results, claiming that the elections had been rigged.

# Coup

On August 30, 2023, a group of military officers, led by General Brice Oligui Nguema, announced that they had taken control of the government. The military officers claimed that they had intervened to prevent a civil war and to restore stability in the country.

## Events

The coup began early in the morning, when a group of soldiers stormed the presidential palace and took control of key government buildings. The soldiers also took control of the national radio and television stations, which were used to broadcast a statement announcing the coup.

General Oligui, a former chief of staff of the Gabonese army, appeared on television to announce the coup. He claimed that the military had intervened to prevent a civil war and to restore stability in the country. He also announced the establishment of a transitional government, which would be headed by a civilian president.

## Arrests of Ali Bongo and other officials

Following the coup, Ali Bongo Ondimba and several other government officials were arrested. Bongo was taken into custody by the military and was held at a military base on the outskirts of the capital city, Libreville.

Other officials who were arrested included the prime minister, Raymond Ndong Sima, and the interior minister, Guy-Bertrand Mapangou. The officials were accused of corruption and abuse of power.

## Proclamation of Brice Oligui as interim president

On August 31, 2023, General Oligui was proclaimed interim president of Gabon by the military. Oligui, a former chief of staff of the Gabonese army, had been a key player in the coup. He promised to restore stability in the country and to hold elections within a year.

# Aftermath

The coup led to a period of uncertainty in Gabon, with many people wondering what the future held for the country.

## Formation of a new government

Following the coup, a new government was formed, with General Oligui as interim president. The government was made up of military officers and civilians, who were tasked with restoring stability in the country.

The new government promised to hold elections within a year and to restore democracy in the country. However, many people were skeptical about the government's intentions, and there were fears that the military would try to hold onto power.

## Bongo's release

On September 10, 2023, Ali Bongo Ondimba was released from custody. Bongo, who had been held at a military base, was released after a meeting with General Oligui.

Bongo was given permission to leave the country, and he flew to Morocco, where he was met by his family. The release of Bongo was seen as a positive step, but many people were still concerned about the future of the country.

# Reactions

The coup was met with a mixture of reactions, both domestically and internationally.

## Domestic

Many Gabonese people welcomed the coup, seeing it as an opportunity for change. However, others were concerned about the future of the country and the intentions of the military.

The opposition parties, who had been critical of Bongo's government, welcomed the coup. They saw it as an opportunity to bring about change and to restore democracy in the country.

## International

The international community was divided in its response to the coup. Some countries, such as France and the United States, condemned the coup and called for the restoration of democracy.

Other countries, such as China and Russia, were more muted in their response. They called for calm and stability in the country, but did not condemn the coup.

The African Union and the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) condemned the coup and called for the restoration of democracy in the country.

Matty Healy
================

Matthew Timothy Healy, known professionally as Matty Healy, is a British singer, songwriter, guitarist, and record producer. He is the lead vocalist and guitarist of the Manchester-based indie rock band The 1975.

Early life
------------

Matty Healy was born on April 19, 1989, in London, England. He is the son of actor Tim Healy and actress Denise Welch. He has one brother, Louis Healy, who is also an actor. Healy's parents divorced when he was young, and he spent his childhood moving between London and Manchester. He attended Wilmslow High School in Cheshire and later studied music at the Manchester College of Music.

Career
--------

### 2002–2011: Beginnings, and early years of the 1975

Healy began his music career at the age of 13, playing guitar in a band with his friends. In 2002, he met his future bandmates, Adam Hann, Ross MacDonald, and George Daniel, at Wilmslow High School. They formed a band called Talkhouse, which later changed its name to Bixby and then The 1975. The band played gigs in the Manchester area and recorded demos, but they didn't gain much attention until 2011.

### 2012–2014: Rise to fame

In 2012, The 1975 released their debut EP, "Facedown," which caught the attention of record labels. They signed with Dirty Hit Records and released their second EP, "Sex," in 2012. The EP's lead single, "The City," gained airplay on BBC Radio 1, and the band began to attract a following. In 2013, they released their third EP, "Music for Cars," which included the hit single "Chocolate." The song became a chart-topper in the UK, and the band's popularity soared.

### 2015–2017: Breakthrough

The 1975 released their self-titled debut album in 2013, which reached number one on the UK Albums Chart. The album's lead single, "Girls," became a hit, and the band embarked on their first world tour. In 2015, they released their second album, "I Like It When You Sleep, for You Are So Beautiful yet So Unaware of It," which debuted at number one on the UK Albums Chart and the US Billboard 200 chart. The album's lead single, "The Sound," became a chart-topper in the UK, and the band's fan base grew rapidly.

### 2018–2021: Critical acclaim

In 2018, The 1975 released their third album, "A Brief Inquiry into Online Relationships," which received widespread critical acclaim. The album's lead single, "Give Yourself a Try," became a hit, and the band embarked on a world tour. In 2019, they released their fourth album, "Notes on a Conditional Form," which debuted at number one on the UK Albums Chart and received positive reviews from critics.

### 2022–present: Further success

In 2022, The 1975 released their fifth album, "Being Funny in a Foreign Language," which debuted at number one on the UK Albums Chart and received positive reviews from critics. The album's lead single, "Part of the Band," became a hit, and the band embarked on a world tour.

Artistry
----------

### Influences

Healy's music style is influenced by a range of genres, including indie rock, pop, electronica, and jazz. He has cited artists such as Talking Heads, The Cure, and Joy Division as influences. He has also mentioned that he is a fan of classical music and has been influenced by composers such as Claude Debussy and Erik Satie.

### Voice

Healy's voice is known for its distinctive tone and range. He has a wide vocal range, and his voice can move from soft and melodic to loud and aggressive. He has been praised for his vocal ability and has been compared to other notable vocalists such as Robert Smith and Morrissey.

### Songwriting

Healy is the primary songwriter for The 1975. He has written or co-written most of the band's songs, and his lyrics often focus on themes of love, relationships, technology, and social commentary. He has been praised for his songwriting ability and has been compared to other notable songwriters such as Paul McCartney and Brian Wilson.

### Performance style

Healy is known for his energetic and charismatic live performances. He is a skilled guitarist and often plays complex guitar parts during live shows. He has also been known to stage dive and crowd surf during performances, and has been praised for his ability to connect with audiences.

Legacy
--------

### Healywave

Healy has been credited with helping to create a new wave of British indie rock music, often referred to as "Healywave." This genre is characterized by its blend of indie rock, pop, and electronica, and has been influenced by Healy's music style. Other bands such as Pale Waves and The Neighbourhood have been associated with the Healywave genre.

Political views and activism
-----------------------------

### LGBTQ+ rights

Healy is a vocal supporter of LGBTQ+ rights. He has been a longtime ally of the LGBTQ+ community and has used his platform to raise awareness and support for LGBTQ+ issues. In 2019, he performed at a benefit concert for the LGBTQ+ charity, Stonewall.

### Climate change mitigation

Healy is a vocal advocate for climate change mitigation. He has spoken out about the need for urgent action to address climate change and has used his platform to raise awareness and support for climate change initiatives. In 2020, he performed at a benefit concert for the climate change charity, Extinction Rebellion.

### Gender issues

Healy has been a vocal advocate for women's rights and has spoken out about the need for greater gender equality. He has used his platform to raise awareness and support for women's rights initiatives and has been a longtime ally of the feminist movement.

### Religion

Healy has been open about his struggles with faith and has spoken out about the need for greater understanding and acceptance of different religions. He has used his platform to raise awareness and support for interfaith initiatives and has been a vocal advocate for greater religious tolerance.

2023 Michigan State University Shooting

On February 13, 2023, a mass shooting occurred at Michigan State University (MSU) in East Lansing, Michigan, United States. The shooting resulted in the deaths of three students and injuries to five others.

# Shootings

The shooting occurred around 8:00 p.m. local time at two locations on the MSU campus: Berkey Hall and the MSU Student Union building. The gunman, who was later identified as Anthony Dwayne McRae, opened fire in the classrooms and hallways of Berkey Hall, before moving to the MSU Student Union building, where he continued to shoot. The shooting lasted for approximately 30 minutes, during which time the university's emergency alert system was activated, warning students and staff to seek shelter.

# Victims

Three students were killed in the shooting: Arielle Anderson, a 19-year-old sophomore; Alexandria Verner, a 20-year-old junior; and Brian Fraser, a 20-year-old junior. Five other students were injured, including three who were in critical condition. The victims were all students at MSU, and the shooting was not believed to be targeted at any specific individual or group.

## Aftermath

Following the shooting, the MSU campus was placed on lockdown, and students and staff were advised to remain in place until the all-clear was given. The university's crisis management team was activated, and emergency responders, including police and medical personnel, were dispatched to the scene. The investigation into the shooting was led by the Michigan State Police, with assistance from the FBI and other law enforcement agencies.

# Perpetrator

Anthony Dwayne McRae, a 43-year-old resident of Lansing, Michigan, was identified as the shooter. McRae had no known connections to MSU or the victims. He was found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound in a nearby parking garage, approximately two hours after the shooting began. McRae had a history of mental health issues and had been known to law enforcement prior to the shooting.

## Aftermath

In the days following the shooting, the MSU community came together to mourn the loss of the victims and support those affected by the tragedy. The university provided counseling services and other forms of support to students and staff.

# Aftermath

## Memorials and Vigils

Memorials and vigils were held on the MSU campus and in the surrounding community to honor the victims of the shooting. Thousands of students, staff, and community members attended the events, which included candlelight vigils, prayer services, and moments of silence.

## Gun Violence Protest

A protest against gun violence was held on the MSU campus, with hundreds of students and community members in attendance. The protest called for stricter gun control laws and greater action to prevent mass shootings.

## Permanent Memorial

A permanent memorial to the victims of the shooting was established on the MSU campus. The memorial, which includes a plaque and a garden, serves as a reminder of the lives lost and the impact of the tragedy on the MSU community.

## Lawsuits

Lawsuits were filed against MSU and other parties in connection with the shooting. The lawsuits alleged that the university had failed to provide adequate security and had not taken sufficient steps to prevent the shooting.

# Responses

## Gun Control Debate

The shooting reignited the debate over gun control laws in the United States. Advocates for stricter gun control laws pointed to the MSU shooting as an example of the need for greater regulation of firearms, while opponents argued that such laws would infringe on Second Amendment rights.

## Connections to Other Shootings

The MSU shooting was compared to other recent mass shootings in the United States, including the 2022 Robb Elementary School shooting and the 2022 Uvalde shooting. The shootings highlighted the ongoing concern over gun violence in the United States and the need for greater action to prevent such tragedies.

2022 French Legislative Election

The 2022 French legislative election was held on 12 and 19 June 2022 to elect the 577 members of the 16th National Assembly of the French Fifth Republic. The election took place after the 2022 French presidential election, in which Emmanuel Macron was re-elected as President of France.

# Background

The 2022 French legislative election was the 16th legislative election of the French Fifth Republic. The previous legislative election was held in 2017, and the National Assembly's term was set to end on 21 June 2022. The election was held during a period of significant change in French politics, marked by the rise of populist and nationalist movements, as well as growing concerns about climate change, economic inequality, and social injustice.

The election was also notable for the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which had a significant effect on French society and economy. The pandemic led to widespread lockdowns, travel restrictions, and economic disruption, which had a profound impact on the lives of French citizens.

# Electoral System

The French legislative election uses a two-round system, with single-member constituencies. In the first round, voters cast ballots for their preferred candidate, and the top two candidates with the most votes in each constituency advance to the second round. In the second round, the candidate with the most votes is elected.

Voters must be at least 18 years old and registered on the electoral roll to participate in the election. Candidates must be at least 18 years old, a French citizen, and meet certain residency requirements.

# Dates

The 2022 French legislative election was held on two separate dates:

* 12 June 2022: First round
* 19 June 2022: Second round

# Major Parties and Alliances

Several major parties and alliances contested the election. The main parties were:

* La République En Marche! (LREM), led by Emmanuel Macron, the incumbent President of France
* Rassemblement National (RN), a far-right nationalist party led by Marine Le Pen
* Les Républicains (LR), a centre-right party led by Christian Jacob
* Parti Socialiste (PS), a centre-left party led by Olivier Faure
* La France Insoumise (LFI), a left-wing party led by Jean-Luc Mélenchon
* Europe Écologie Les Verts (EELV), a green party led by Julien Bayou

## Deputies not Standing for Reelection

Several high-profile deputies announced that they would not stand for re-election, including:

* Edouard Philippe, the former Prime Minister of France
* Christophe Castaner, the former Minister of the Interior
* Mounir Mahjoubi, the former Secretary of State for Digital Affairs
* Delphine Batho, a former Minister of Ecology

# Opinion Polls

Opinion polls conducted in the lead-up to the election suggested a tight contest between the main parties. A poll conducted by Ipsos in May 2022 found that LREM was leading with 28% of the vote, followed by RN with 22%, LR with 13%, PS with 10%, LFI with 9%, and EELV with 7%.

# Results

## First Round

The first round of the election was held on 12 June 2022. The turnout was 47.5%, down from 48.7% in the 2017 election. The results were as follows:

* LREM: 25.8% of the vote
* RN: 19.1% of the vote
* LR: 11.3% of the vote
* PS: 9.1% of the vote
* LFI: 8.1% of the vote
* EELV: 6.2% of the vote

## Second Round

The second round of the election was held on 19 June 2022. The turnout was 46.2%, down from 48.7% in the 2017 election. The results were as follows:

* LREM: 38.6% of the vote
* RN: 17.3% of the vote
* LR: 11.2% of the vote
* PS: 8.8% of the vote
* LFI: 7.7% of the vote
* EELV: 6.5% of the vote

## National Results

The national results were as follows:

* LREM: 245 seats
* RN: 89 seats
* LR: 61 seats
* PS: 27 seats
* LFI: 22 seats
* EELV: 23 seats

## Results by Constituency

The results by constituency were as follows:

* LREM won 245 constituencies
* RN won 89 constituencies
* LR won 61 constituencies
* PS won 27 constituencies
* LFI won 22 constituencies
* EELV won 23 constituencies

## Electorate

The electorate was composed of 48.7 million registered voters, with a turnout of 47.5% in the first round and 46.2% in the second round.

# Aftermath

## Formation of Parliamentary Groups

The formation of parliamentary groups took place in the days following the election. The main parliamentary groups were:

* La République En Marche! (LREM)
* Rassemblement National (RN)
* Les Républicains (LR)
* Parti Socialiste (PS)
* La France Insoumise (LFI)
* Europe Écologie Les Verts (EELV)

## Vote of No Confidence

A vote of no confidence was held on 5 July 2022, which was rejected by a majority of 246 votes to 198.

Halloween Ends

Halloween Ends is a 2022 American slasher film directed by David Gordon Green and written by Green, Danny McBride, and Paul Brad Logan. The film is the thirteenth installment in the Halloween franchise and serves as a direct sequel to the 2020 film Halloween Kills. The story follows Laurie Strode as she prepares for a final confrontation with Michael Myers.

# Plot

The film takes place four years after the events of Halloween Kills. Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) is living with her granddaughter Allyson (Andi Matichak) and is writing a memoir about her experiences with Michael Myers. However, a series of events leads Laurie to believe that Michael is not dead, as previously thought. As the city of Haddonfield prepares for Halloween, Laurie must confront her past and face Michael once again.

Meanwhile, a new character, Corey Cunningham (Rohan Campbell), is introduced. Corey is a young man who is struggling to find his place in the world. He becomes involved with Allyson, but his presence also attracts the attention of Michael, leading to a series of violent events.

As the story unfolds, Laurie and Allyson find themselves in a desperate fight for survival against Michael. Along the way, they must also confront their own personal demons and the legacy of trauma that has haunted their family for decades.

# Cast

* Jamie Lee Curtis as Laurie Strode
* Andi Matichak as Allyson Nelson
* Rohan Campbell as Corey Cunningham
* Will Patton as Deputy Frank Hawkins
* Kyle Richards as Lindsey Wallace
* James Jude Courtney as Michael Myers

# Production

## Development

Halloween Ends was officially announced in July 2020, with David Gordon Green set to return as director. The film was produced by Jason Blum, Malek Akkad, and Bill Block, with a script written by Green, Danny McBride, and Paul Brad Logan.

## Writing

The script for Halloween Ends was written by Green, McBride, and Logan. The story was developed in collaboration with the cast, particularly Jamie Lee Curtis, who had a significant amount of input on the direction of the film.

## Casting

The cast of Halloween Ends includes returning stars Jamie Lee Curtis, Andi Matichak, and Will Patton. Rohan Campbell was cast as the new character Corey Cunningham, while Kyle Richards reprised her role as Lindsey Wallace.

## Filming

Principal photography for Halloween Ends began in January 2022 and wrapped in March 2022. The film was shot on location in Wilmington, North Carolina, and surrounding areas.

## Post-production

Post-production for Halloween Ends began in April 2022 and was completed in September 2022. The film's editor was Tim Alverson, who worked closely with Green to develop the film's pacing and tone.

## Music

The score for Halloween Ends was composed by John Carpenter, Cody Carpenter, and Daniel Davies. The soundtrack features a mix of original music and classic Halloween themes.

# Release

Halloween Ends was released in the United States on October 14, 2022. The film was distributed by Universal Pictures and was released in theaters and on streaming platforms.

## Home media

Halloween Ends was released on DVD, Blu-ray, and digital platforms on December 27, 2022. The home media release includes a number of bonus features, including deleted scenes and behind-the-scenes footage.

# Reception

## Audience viewership

Halloween Ends was a commercial success, grossing over $130 million worldwide. The film received a mixed reaction from audiences, with some fans praising the film's conclusion to the series, while others felt that it did not live up to expectations.

## Box office

Halloween Ends opened at number one at the box office, grossing $40 million in its opening weekend. The film went on to gross over $60 million in the United States and over $70 million internationally.

## Critical response

Halloween Ends received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the film's performances and direction, while others felt that it was too formulaic and predictable. The film holds a 47% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 222 reviews, with an average rating of 5.2/10.

## Accolades

Halloween Ends was nominated for several awards, including a Saturn Award for Best Horror Film and a Fangoria Chainsaw Award for Best Wide-Release Film.

# Future

Halloween Ends is the final film in the Halloween franchise, with Jamie Lee Curtis stating that she will not reprise her role as Laurie Strode again. However, it is possible that the franchise may be rebooted or reimagined in the future.

article:
Banjska Attack
===============

The Banjska attack was a military assault that took place on July 14, 1999, in the village of Banjska, located in the Zvečan municipality of Kosovo. The attack was carried out by the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) against a group of Yugoslav Army soldiers and civilians. The incident occurred during the Kosovo War, a conflict between the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and the Kosovo Albanian separatist movement.

Background
----------

The Kosovo War was a conflict between the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and the Kosovo Albanian separatist movement, which began in 1998. The war was sparked by a long-standing dispute over Kosovo's status, which was a province of Serbia within Yugoslavia. The Kosovo Albanian population, which made up the majority of the province's population, sought independence, while the Serbian government wanted to maintain control over the region. The conflict escalated into a full-scale war in 1999, with the Yugoslav Army and Serbian paramilitary groups clashing with the KLA.

Attack
------

The Banjska attack occurred on July 14, 1999, when a group of KLA fighters ambushed a convoy of Yugoslav Army soldiers and civilians in the village of Banjska. The attack was carried out using a combination of small arms and explosives.

### Weaponry

The KLA fighters used a variety of weapons during the attack, including assault rifles, machine guns, and rocket-propelled grenades. The Yugoslav Army soldiers were also armed with small arms and explosives.

### Attackers

The KLA fighters who carried out the attack were reportedly from the 113th Brigade, which was a unit of the KLA's Zvečan Operational Zone. The brigade was responsible for carrying out attacks against Yugoslav Army and Serbian paramilitary targets in the region.

### Casualties

The attack resulted in the deaths of 14 Yugoslav Army soldiers and 4 civilians. In addition, several soldiers and civilians were injured during the attack. The KLA also suffered casualties, although the exact number is unknown.

Aftermath
----------

The Banjska attack was widely condemned by the international community, including the United States, the European Union, and the United Nations. The attack was seen as a serious escalation of the conflict in Kosovo and raised concerns about the potential for further violence in the region.

### Resolutions

#### Kosovo and Albania

The Kosovo Albanian leadership, including the KLA, condemned the attack and expressed regret for the loss of life. However, they also stated that the attack was a legitimate response to the Yugoslav Army's actions in Kosovo.

Albania, which had provided support to the KLA, also condemned the attack and called for a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

#### European Union

The European Union condemned the attack and called for an immediate ceasefire. The EU also expressed concern about the humanitarian situation in Kosovo and called for greater access for aid organizations.

### Serbian state involvement

The Yugoslav government, led by President Slobodan Milošević, denied any involvement in the attack and blamed the KLA for the violence. However, there were reports that Serbian paramilitary groups had been involved in the attack, and that the Yugoslav Army had provided support to the groups.

### Serbian military buildup and base construction

Following the attack, the Yugoslav Army increased its presence in the region and began constructing new military bases. The move was seen as an attempt to increase the Yugoslav Army's control over the region and to prevent further KLA attacks.

Reactions
---------

### Kosovo

The KLA and the Kosovo Albanian leadership condemned the attack and expressed regret for the loss of life. However, they also stated that the attack was a legitimate response to the Yugoslav Army's actions in Kosovo.

### Serbia

The Yugoslav government, led by President Slobodan Milošević, denied any involvement in the attack and blamed the KLA for the violence. The government also claimed that the attack was part of a larger conspiracy to destabilize the region.

### International

The international community widely condemned the attack and called for an immediate ceasefire. The United States, the European Union, and the United Nations all expressed concern about the humanitarian situation in Kosovo and called for greater access for aid organizations.

The Banjska attack was a significant escalation of the conflict in Kosovo and highlighted the need for a peaceful resolution to the crisis. The attack also raised concerns about the potential for further violence in the region and the need for greater international involvement to prevent a wider conflict.

article:
Salman Rushdie

Sir Salman Rushdie is a British-Indian novelist and essayist. He is one of the most celebrated and influential writers of his generation, known for his complex and often provocative novels that blend elements of magical realism, historical fiction, and postcolonial critique. Rushdie's works have been translated into numerous languages and have received widespread critical acclaim, as well as controversy and even violence.

#Early life and education

Salman Rushdie was born on June 19, 1947, in Bombay (now Mumbai), India, to Anis Ahmed Rushdie and Negin Bhatt. His father was a lawyer and a devout Muslim, while his mother was a teacher and a secularist. Rushdie's family was part of the Kashmiri Muslim community, and he was raised in a culturally and linguistically diverse environment. He was the eldest of four children, and his parents encouraged his love of literature and learning from an early age.

Rushdie attended the Cathedral and John Connon School in Bombay before moving to England to study at King's College, Cambridge. He earned a degree in history from Cambridge in 1968 and later earned a master's degree in philosophy from the University of East Anglia. After completing his education, Rushdie worked as a copywriter in London and began writing fiction in his spare time.

#Career

##Copywriter

Rushdie worked as a copywriter in London from 1970 to 1980, writing advertising copy for various agencies. During this period, he also began writing fiction and published several short stories in literary magazines.

##Literary works

###Early works and literary breakthrough, 1975–1987

Rushdie's first novel, "Grimus," was published in 1975 to mixed reviews. However, his second novel, "Midnight's Children," published in 1981, received widespread critical acclaim and established him as a major literary talent. The novel won the Booker Prize in 1981 and the James Tait Black Memorial Prize in 1982. Rushdie's subsequent novels, "Shame" (1983) and "The Satanic Verses" (1988), solidified his reputation as a bold and innovative writer.

###The Satanic Verses and Haroun and the Sea of Stories, 1988–1990

"The Satanic Verses" was published in 1988 and sparked widespread controversy and outrage in the Muslim world. The novel was seen as blasphemous and insulting to Islam, and Rushdie received death threats and a fatwa from Ayatollah Khomeini, the Supreme Leader of Iran. The controversy surrounding the novel led to Rushdie going into hiding for several years. During this period, he wrote "Haroun and the Sea of Stories" (1990), a children's novel that explores themes of storytelling and identity.

###Further works, 1990s–2000s

Rushdie continued to write prolifically throughout the 1990s and 2000s, publishing novels such as "The Moor's Last Sigh" (1995), "The Ground Beneath Her Feet" (1999), and "Fury" (2001). His nonfiction works, including "Imaginary Homelands" (1991) and "Step Across This Line" (2002), explored themes of identity, culture, and politics.

###Later works, novels, and essays, 2015–2024

Rushdie's more recent works include the novels "Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights" (2015), "The Golden House" (2017), and "Quichotte" (2019). His essays and nonfiction works, such as "Language & Silence" (2019) and "Victory City" (2023), continue to explore themes of language, culture, and politics.

##Critical reception

Rushdie's works have received widespread critical acclaim for their complex and nuanced exploration of themes such as identity, culture, and politics. However, his works have also been criticized for their perceived blasphemy and insults to Islam. The controversy surrounding "The Satanic Verses" led to Rushdie going into hiding for several years and receiving a fatwa from Ayatollah Khomeini.

##Academic and other activities

Rushdie has taught at various universities, including the University of East Anglia and Emory University. He has also been a fellow at the Royal Society of Literature and a president of the PEN American Center. Rushdie has been involved in various human rights and freedom of expression initiatives, including the defense of persecuted writers and the promotion of literary freedom.

##Film and television

Rushdie's works have been adapted into films and television series, including the 1996 film "Midnight's Children" and the 2012 television series "The Reluctant Fundamentalist." Rushdie has also written screenplays and has been involved in various film and television projects.

#The Satanic Verses and the fatwā

##Failed assassination attempt (1989)

In 1989, Rushdie survived an assassination attempt by a group of Iranian militants. The attempt was widely seen as a response to the publication of "The Satanic Verses."

###Hezbollah's comments (2006)

In 2006, Hezbollah's leader, Hassan Nasrallah, reiterated the fatwa against Rushdie, calling for his death.

##International Guerillas (1990)

Rushdie's subsequent novel, "Haroun and the Sea of Stories," was seen as a response to the controversy surrounding "The Satanic Verses." However, the novel was also criticized for its perceived insults to Islam.

##Al-Qaeda hit list (2010)

In 2010, Al-Qaeda released a hit list of public figures, including Rushdie, who were seen as enemies of Islam.

##Jaipur Literature Festival (2012)

In 2012, Rushdie was scheduled to appear at the Jaipur Literature Festival, but he canceled his appearance due to threats from Muslim extremists.

##Chautauqua attack (2022)

In 2022, Rushdie was attacked on stage at the Chautauqua Institution in New York by a Muslim extremist. Rushdie suffered serious injuries, including a punctured lung and damage to his liver.

#Awards, honours, and recognition

##Knighthood

Rushdie was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in 2007 for his services to literature.

#Religious and political beliefs

##Religious background

Rushdie was born into a Muslim family and was raised in a culturally and linguistically diverse environment. However, he has stated that he is an atheist and has been critical of religious extremism.

##Political background

###UK politics

Rushdie has been critical of British politics and has been involved in various human rights and freedom of expression initiatives.

###US politics

Rushdie has been critical of American politics and has been involved in various human rights and freedom of expression initiatives.

###Against religious extremism

Rushdie has been a vocal critic of religious extremism and has spoken out against the persecution of writers and artists.

###South Asian politics and Kashmir

Rushdie has been involved in various initiatives promoting peace and reconciliation in South Asia, particularly in Kashmir.

#Personal life

Rushdie has been married four times and has two sons. He is currently married to the American writer and activist, Padma Lakshmi.

#Bibliography

2022 Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly Election

The 2022 Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly election was held on November 12, 2022, to elect 68 members of the Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly. The term of the current assembly was set to expire on January 8, 2023. The election was a significant event in the state's politics, with the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) seeking to retain power and the opposition parties aiming to capture the assembly.

# Background

Himachal Pradesh has a tradition of alternating governments between the BJP and the Indian National Congress (INC). The state has a history of voting out the incumbent government, making the election a challenging task for the ruling party.

## Bypolls and defections

In the run-up to the election, several bypolls were held in the state, which saw the INC performing well. The BJP also suffered from defections, with some of its prominent leaders switching to the INC. These developments were seen as a setback for the BJP and boosted the morale of the INC.

# Schedule

The election schedule was announced by the Election Commission of India (ECI) on October 14, 2022. The ECI announced that the election would be held on November 12, 2022, and the counting of votes would take place on December 8, 2022.

# Election statistics

The election saw a total of 55,92,828 electors, including 27,37,845 male and 28,55,039 female voters. The state had 7,881 polling stations, with 7,235 stations located in rural areas and 646 in urban areas.

# Parties and alliances

The election saw several parties and alliances in the fray. The main parties were the BJP, the INC, the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), and the Left Front.

## National Democratic Alliance

The BJP, which is part of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), contested the election alone. The party fielded candidates in all 68 constituencies.

## United Progressive Alliance

The INC, which is part of the United Progressive Alliance (UPA), also contested the election alone. The party fielded candidates in all 68 constituencies.

## Aam Aadmi Party

The AAP, which is a relatively new entrant in the state's politics, contested the election alone. The party fielded candidates in 67 constituencies.

## Left Front

The Left Front, which is an alliance of the Communist Party of India (Marxist) and the Communist Party of India, contested the election alone. The party fielded candidates in 11 constituencies.

## Others

Several other parties, including the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) and the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD), also contested the election. However, they failed to make a significant impact.

# Candidates

A total of 412 candidates contested the election. The BJP fielded 68 candidates, the INC fielded 68 candidates, the AAP fielded 67 candidates, and the Left Front fielded 11 candidates.

# Campaigns

The election campaign saw several high-profile leaders from various parties campaigning in the state. The BJP's campaign was led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who addressed several rallies in the state. The INC's campaign was led by party president Mallikarjun Kharge, who also addressed several rallies.

## Aam Aadmi Party

The AAP's campaign was led by party chief Arvind Kejriwal, who addressed several rallies in the state. The party's campaign focused on issues such as corruption, unemployment, and healthcare.

### Manifesto

The AAP released its election manifesto on October 25, 2022. The manifesto promised several populist measures, including free electricity, free water, and free healthcare. The party also promised to create jobs and improve the state's infrastructure.

## Bharatiya Janata Party

The BJP's campaign focused on the party's achievements in the state, including the implementation of several development projects. The party also attacked the INC on issues such as corruption and misgovernance.

### Manifesto

The BJP released its election manifesto on November 4, 2022. The manifesto promised several measures to improve the state's economy, including the creation of jobs and the promotion of tourism. The party also promised to improve the state's infrastructure and healthcare services.

## Indian National Congress

The INC's campaign focused on issues such as unemployment, inflation, and corruption. The party attacked the BJP on its handling of the economy and its alleged failure to deliver on its promises.

### Manifesto

The INC released its election manifesto on October 30, 2022. The manifesto promised several measures to improve the state's economy, including the creation of jobs and the promotion of industries. The party also promised to improve the state's infrastructure and healthcare services.

# Surveys and polls

Several opinion polls were conducted in the state before the election. The polls showed a close contest between the BJP and the INC, with the AAP emerging as a possible spoiler.

## Opinion polls

A survey conducted by the India Today Group in October 2022 showed the BJP leading the INC by a narrow margin. The survey showed the BJP winning 35-40 seats, the INC winning 25-30 seats, and the AAP winning 5-10 seats.

## Exit polls

Several exit polls were conducted on the day of the election. The exit polls showed a close contest between the BJP and the INC, with the AAP emerging as a possible spoiler. A survey conducted by the NewsX channel showed the BJP winning 32-38 seats, the INC winning 26-32 seats, and the AAP winning 4-8 seats.

# Voter turnout

The election saw a high voter turnout, with 75.6% of the electors casting their votes. The highest turnout was recorded in the Kinnaur district, where 84.6% of the electors cast their votes.

# Results

The counting of votes took place on December 8, 2022. The results showed a close contest between the BJP and the INC, with the AAP emerging as a possible spoiler.

## Results by alliance and party

The results showed the INC winning 40 seats, the BJP winning 25 seats, and the AAP winning 3 seats. The Left Front won 1 seat, and the BSP and the SAD won 1 seat each.

## Results by division

The results showed the INC winning 14 seats in the Kangra division, 10 seats in the Mandi division, and 8 seats in the Shimla division. The BJP won 7 seats in the Kangra division, 5 seats in the Mandi division, and 4 seats in the Shimla division.

## Results by district

The results showed the INC winning 5 seats in the Kangra district, 4 seats in the Mandi district, and 3 seats in the Shimla district. The BJP won 3 seats in the Kangra district, 2 seats in the Mandi district, and 1 seat in the Shimla district.

## Results by constituency

The results showed the INC winning several key constituencies, including the Shimla Rural constituency, which was won by the party's chief ministerial candidate, Sukhvinder Singh Sukhu. The BJP won several key constituencies, including the Arki constituency, which was won by the party's chief ministerial candidate, Suresh Bhardwaj.

article:
2022 United States House of Representatives Elections in New York

The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in New York were held on November 8, 2022, to elect the 26 U.S. Representatives from the state of New York, one from each of the state's 26 congressional districts. The elections coincided with other elections to the House of Representatives, elections to the United States Senate, and various state and local elections.

# 2020-22 Redistricting Controversy

The 2022 elections were the first to be held under new congressional district boundaries, which were determined by the New York State Legislature and signed into law by Governor Kathy Hochul in February 2022. The redistricting process was contentious, with critics arguing that the new maps unfairly favored Democratic candidates. A lawsuit challenging the maps was filed in state court, but ultimately, the new boundaries were upheld by the New York Court of Appeals.

# Overview

## Votes by Ballot Line

In New York, candidates can run on multiple ballot lines, representing different parties or organizations. The votes for each candidate are reported separately by ballot line.

## Votes by District

The votes for each district are reported separately, with the winner being the candidate who receives the most votes in that district.

## Seat Allocation

New York has 26 congressional districts, each electing one member to the U.S. House of Representatives. The seats are allocated based on the population of each district.

# District 1

## Republican/Conservative Nominee

### Eliminated in Primary

* Jay Schneiderman

### Withdrawn / Disqualified

* None

### Primary Results

## Democratic/Working Families Nominee

## General Election

* Inside Elections: Leans Democratic
* Sabato's Crystal Ball: Leans Democratic

### Results

* Bridget Fleming (D) won the general election with 50.1% of the vote

# District 2

### Primary Results

* Andrew Garbarino won the Republican primary unopposed

## Democratic Nominee

article:
Death of Mahsa Amini

The death of Mahsa Amini was a highly publicized incident that occurred on September 16, 2022, in Tehran, Iran. Amini, a 22-year-old Kurdish Iranian woman, died in hospital after being arrested by the Guidance Patrol, a unit of Iran's Law Enforcement Command responsible for enforcing the country's strict dress code laws. The circumstances surrounding her death sparked widespread protests and international condemnation, with many calling for greater freedoms and an end to the country's authoritarian regime.

#Background

##Victim

Mahsa Amini was born on September 20, 1999, in Saqqez, Kurdistan Province, Iran. She was a Kurdish Iranian woman who was visiting Tehran with her family when she was arrested by the Guidance Patrol. Amini was a student and had no prior history of activism or involvement in politics.

#Circumstances of death

On September 13, 2022, Amini was arrested by the Guidance Patrol in Tehran for allegedly violating Iran's strict dress code laws. Sh

article:
2022 Little League World Series Results

The 2022 Little League World Series was the 76th edition of the Little League World Series, a baseball tournament for children aged 10 to 12 years old. The tournament was held from August 17 to 28, 2022, in South Williamsport, Pennsylvania. The event featured 16 teams from around the world, competing in a double-elimination stage followed by a single-elimination stage.

# Double-elimination stage

The double-elimination stage was held from August 17 to 24, 2022. The 16 teams were divided into two brackets: the United States bracket and the International bracket. Each team played a minimum of three games in the double-elimination stage.

## United States

The United States bracket featured eight teams from different regions of the country. The teams were:

* Great Lakes: Hingham, Massachusetts
* Mid-Atlantic: Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania
* Midwest: Davenport, Iowa
* New England: Falmouth, Maine
* Northwest: Bend, Oregon
* Southeast: Nolensville, Tennessee
* Southwest: Pearland, Texas
* West: Honolulu, Hawaii

The winners of the United States bracket were Hawaii, who defeated Pennsylvania 13-3 in the championship game.

## International

The International bracket featured eight teams from different countries and regions. The teams were:

* Asia-Pacific: Taipei, Taiwan
* Australia: Brisbane, Australia
* Canada: Vancouver, British Columbia
* Caribbean: Willemstad, Curaçao
* Europe-Africa: Emilia-Romagna, Italy
* Japan: Tokyo, Japan
* Latin America: Maracaibo, Venezuela
* Mexico: Guadalupe, Mexico

The winners of the International bracket were Taiwan, who defeated Japan 2-0 in the championship game.

# Single-elimination stage

The single-elimination stage was held from August 25 to 28, 2022. The winners of the United States and International brackets played each other in the semifinals, with the winners advancing to the championship game.

In the semifinals, Taiwan defeated Pennsylvania 5-2, while Hawaii defeated Curaçao 6-1. In the championship game, Taiwan defeated Hawaii 2-0 to win the 2022 Little League World Series.

# References

# External links

* Official website of the Little League World Series

article:
Vladimir Putin

Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin is a Russian politician and former intelligence officer who has served as the President of Russia since 2012, with the exception of a four-year period from 2008 to 2012. He is one of the most powerful and influential leaders in the world, known for his authoritarian style of governance and his efforts to reassert Russia's global influence.

#Early life

Vladimir Putin was born on October 7, 1952, in Leningrad, Soviet Union (now Saint Petersburg, Russia). His father, Vladimir Spiridonovich Putin, was a conscript in the Soviet Navy, and his mother, Maria Ivanovna Shelomova, was a factory worker. Putin's family lived in a communal apartment in Leningrad, where he grew up with his parents and two siblings. Putin's early life was marked by hardship and struggle, with his family often relying on the charity of relatives to get by.

#Education

Putin attended School No. 193 in Leningrad, where he was an average student but excelled in sports, particularly judo and sambo. He graduated from high school in 1970 and went on to study law at Leningrad State University. Putin graduated from university in 1975 and began working for the KGB, the Soviet Union's security agency.

#KGB career

Putin joined the KGB in 1975 and underwent training at the 401st KGB School in Okhta, Leningrad. He was assigned to the First Chief Directorate, which was responsible for foreign intelligence gathering. Putin worked in East Germany from 1985 to 1990, where he gathered intelligence on the government and opposition groups. He returned to Leningrad in 1990 and worked in the KGB's counterintelligence department.

#Political career

##1990–1996: Saint Petersburg administration

After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Putin entered politics in Saint Petersburg, where he worked as an advisor to the city's mayor, Anatoly Sobchak. Putin quickly rose through the ranks and became the city's deputy mayor in 1994. He played a key role in attracting foreign investment to the city and helped to establish Saint Petersburg as a major economic hub.

##1996–1999: Early Moscow career

In 1996, Putin moved to Moscow, where he worked in the presidential administration under Boris Yeltsin. He quickly gained the trust of Yeltsin, who appointed him as the head of the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor agency to the KGB. Putin's time at the FSB was marked by controversy, with allegations of human rights abuses and corruption.

##1999: First premiership

In August 1999, Yeltsin appointed Putin as the Prime Minister of Russia, following the resignation of Sergei Stepashin. Putin's appointment was seen as a surprise, but he quickly gained popularity due to his tough stance on corruption and his efforts to stabilize the economy.

##1999–2000: Acting presidency

On December 31, 1999, Yeltsin resigned as President of Russia, and Putin became the acting president. Putin's first major challenge was the Second Chechen War, which had begun in August 1999. Putin's handling of the war was widely praised, and he gained a reputation as a strong and decisive leader.

##2000–2004: First presidential term

In March 2000, Putin was elected as the President of Russia, winning 53% of the vote. Putin's first term was marked by efforts to reform the economy and to strengthen the state. He introduced a new tax code, which reduced taxes and encouraged foreign investment. Putin also oversaw the establishment of the Russian Federation's seven federal districts, which were designed to improve governance and reduce corruption.

##2004–2008: Second presidential term

In March 2004, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia, winning 71% of the vote. Putin's second term was marked by efforts to reassert Russia's global influence and to challenge the dominance of the United States. Putin's presidency was also marked by controversy, with allegations of human rights abuses and corruption.

##2008–2012: Second premiership

In March 2008, Putin stepped down as President of Russia, due to constitutional term limits. He was succeeded by Dmitry Medvedev, who appointed Putin as the Prime Minister of Russia. Putin's second term as prime minister was marked by efforts to stabilize the economy, following the 2008 global financial crisis.

##2012–2018: Third presidential term

In March 2012, Putin was elected as the President of Russia, winning 64% of the vote. Putin's third term was marked by efforts to reassert Russia's global influence and to challenge the dominance of the United States. Putin's presidency was also marked by controversy, with allegations of human rights abuses and corruption.

###Annexation of Crimea

In March 2014, Putin annexed Crimea, following a disputed referendum. The annexation was widely condemned by the international community, and it led to a deterioration in relations between Russia and the West.

###Intervention in Syria

In September 2015, Putin launched a military intervention in Syria, in support of the government of Bashar al-Assad. The intervention was widely criticized by the international community, and it led to a deterioration in relations between Russia and the West.

###Russia's interference in the 2016 US election

In 2016, Putin was accused of interfering in the US presidential election, in support of Donald Trump. The allegations were widely condemned by the international community, and they led to a deterioration in relations between Russia and the West.

##2018–2024: Fourth presidential term

#Early life

Clarissa Eden was born on June 28, 1920, into a family of minor nobility. Her early life was marked by a series of moves between different parts of Europe, which would later shape her cosmopolitan outlook and love of travel.

##Paris, Tuscany and London (1937–1939)

In 1939, the family returned to London, where Clarissa would spend much of her adult life.

Charles III (Charles Philip Arthur George; born November 14, 1948) is the King of the United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms. He was the longest-serving heir apparent in British history, serving in that role for over 68 years. Charles became King following the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, on September 8, 2022.

#Early life, family, and education

Charles was born at Buckingham Palace in London, England, to Princess Elizabeth, Duchess of Edinburgh (later Queen Elizabeth II), and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh. He was the eldest of four children, with three siblings: Anne, Prince Andrew, and Prince Edward. Charles's early life was marked by a strong sense of duty and tradition, as he was groomed from a young age to one day take on the role of monarch.

Charles was educated at Cheam School in Berkshire, Gordonstoun School in Scotland, and Trinity College, Cambridge. At Cambridge, he studied archaeology and anthropology, graduating with a 2:2 degree in 1970. Charles also spent time at the University of Wales, Aberystwyth, where he learned Welsh, a language he has continued to speak fluently throughout his life.

#Prince of Wales

##Military training and career

Following his graduation from Cambridge, Charles began his military training, attending the Royal Air Force College Cranwell and the Royal Naval College Dartmouth. He served in the Royal Air Force and the Royal Navy, eventually becoming a commander in the latter. Charles's military career lasted for several years, during which time he saw active duty in the Falklands War.

##Relationships and marriages

###Bachelorhood

Charles's early life was marked by a string of high-profile relationships, including those with Lady Georgiana Russell, Lady Jane Wellesley, and Lucia Flecha de Lima. However, it was his relationship with Lady Diana Spencer that would ultimately lead to marriage.

Charles met Lady Diana Spencer in 1977, and the two began a romantic relationship. They became engaged in February 1981, and were married on July 29, 1981, at St. Paul's Cathedral in London. The wedding was watched by an estimated global audience of 750 million people. Charles and Diana had two sons, Prince William and Prince Harry, before their divorce in 1996.

###Camilla Parker Bowles

Charles met Camilla Parker Bowles in 1970, and the two began a romantic relationship. However, due to his family's disapproval, Charles ended the relationship and married Lady Diana Spencer instead. Charles and Camilla rekindled their romance in the late 1990s, and were married in a civil ceremony on April 9, 2005.

##Official duties

As Prince of Wales, Charles carried out numerous official duties, including representing the Queen at events and engagements around the world. He also became known for his philanthropic work, supporting a wide range of charitable causes and organizations.

#Reign

Charles became King following the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, on September 8, 2022. He was proclaimed King by the Accession Council, and was formally crowned in a coronation ceremony at Westminster Abbey.

#Health

##Diet

Charles has been a long-time advocate for healthy eating and living. He has spoken publicly about the importance of a balanced diet, and has been known to follow a largely vegetarian diet.

#Charity work

Charles has been involved with numerous charitable causes throughout his life, supporting organizations that work on issues such as poverty, education, and healthcare. He has also been a vocal advocate for environmental causes, and has spoken out on issues such as climate change and conservation.

##Investigations of donations

##Natural environment

##Alternative medicine

However, his views on alternative medicine have been the subject of controversy, with some critics accusing him of promoting unproven and unscientific treatments.

##Sports

##Visual, performing, and literary arts

Charles has a deep appreciation for the arts, and has been involved with numerous cultural institutions throughout his life. He has been a patron of the Royal Opera House, the Royal Shakespeare Company, and the National Theatre, among others.

##Religion and philosophy

Charles has spoken publicly about the importance of spirituality and faith in his life. He has been a member of the Church of England throughout his life, and has spoken about the influence of Christian teachings on his values and worldview.

#Media image and public opinion

##Reaction to press treatment

#Residences and finance

Charles has a number of official residences, including Clarence House in London and Highgrove House in Gloucestershire. He also has a number of private residences, including Birkhall in Scotland and a home in Wales.

#Titles, styles, honours, and arms

##Titles and styles

Charles has held numerous titles and styles throughout his life, including Prince of Wales, Earl of Chester, and Duke of Cornwall. As King, he is known as Charles III.

##Arms

Saw X is an upcoming American horror film directed by Darren Lynn Bousman and written by Josh Stolberg and Peter Goldfinger. It is the tenth installment in the Saw franchise and stars Tobin Bell, Shawnee Smith, and Synnøve Macody Lund. The film is scheduled to be released in October 2023.

##Casting

##Filming

##Post-production

2022 in Video Games

The year 2022 was a significant period for the video game industry, marked by the release of highly anticipated games, advancements in hardware technology, and notable events that shaped the gaming community. This article provides an overview of the major happenings in the world of video games during 2022.

# Top-rated Games

## Major Awards

Several major awards ceremonies took place in 2022, recognizing outstanding achievements in game development. The Game Awards 2022 honored the best games of the year, with Elden Ring taking home the coveted Game of the Year award. The DICE Awards and the Golden Joystick Awards also acknowledged excellence in game design, storytelling, and overall gaming experience.

## Critically Acclaimed Games

* Elden Ring (Action role-playing game)

* Xenoblade Chronicles 3 (Role-playing game)

These games were praised for their captivating narratives, stunning visuals, and addictive gameplay, solidifying their places among the best games of 2022.

# Financial Performance

The video game industry experienced significant financial growth in 2022, with many games generating substantial revenue. The global gaming market was estimated to have reached $190 billion in revenue, with the PC gaming market accounting for the largest share.

Several games achieved remarkable commercial success, including:

* Elden Ring (over 12 million copies sold)
* Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II (over 10 million copies sold)

These figures demonstrate the immense popularity and financial viability of the video game industry in 2022.

# Major Events

## Ukrainian Support

Notable examples of Ukrainian support included:

* CD Projekt's donation of 1 million PLN to the Polish Red Cross for Ukrainian aid

These efforts demonstrate the gaming community's capacity for empathy and solidarity in times of crisis.

# Notable Deaths

article:
2022 Luzon Earthquake

On July 27, 2022, a powerful earthquake struck the island of Luzon in the Philippines, causing widespread destruction and loss of life. The earthquake was felt across several provinces, with the greatest impact in the northern regions of Abra, Ilocos Sur, and Benguet.

# Earthquake

## Characteristics

The 2022 Luzon earthquake occurred at 8:43 AM local time, with its epicenter located in the town of Lagangilang, Abra, approximately 11 kilometers northwest of the provincial capital, Bangued. The United States Geological Survey (USGS) reported the earthquake's magnitude as 7.0 on the moment magnitude scale (Mw), while the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (PHIVOLCS) recorded a magnitude of 7.3. The earthquake's focal depth was estimated at 17 kilometers.

## Aftershocks

Following the main shock, numerous aftershocks were recorded, with some exceeding magnitude 5.0. The strongest aftershock, with a magnitude of 5.4, occurred approximately 30 minutes after the main shock. The aftershocks continued for several days, with some still being felt weeks after the initial earthquake.

## Intensity

The earthquake's intensity was reported as VIII (Very Destructive) on the PHIVOLCS Earthquake Intensity Scale (PEIS), with some areas experiencing even higher intensities. In Abra, where the epicenter was located, the intensity was reported as IX (Destructive), while in Ilocos Sur and Benguet, the intensity was reported as VIII (Very Destructive).

## Tsunami

Despite the earthquake's proximity to the coast, no tsunami was triggered. The Philippine Tsunami Warning System issued a tsunami advisory, but it was later cancelled as no tsunami waves were detected.

## Liquefaction

In some areas, particularly in Abra and Ilocos Sur, liquefaction occurred, resulting in the formation of sand boils and mud volcanoes. Liquefaction is a phenomenon where shaking causes water-saturated soil to lose its strength, leading to the formation of unstable ground.

# Response

## International aid

The international community provided assistance to the affected areas, with several countries offering aid and support. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) activated the international humanitarian response, with various agencies providing support in areas such as search and rescue, shelter, and food.

# Impact

## Abra

Abra was the hardest-hit province, with widespread destruction reported in the capital, Bangued, and surrounding areas. The province's infrastructure, including roads, bridges, and buildings, suffered significant damage. The provincial government reported over 1,000 homes destroyed and thousands more damaged.

## Baguio

In Baguio, the summer capital of the Philippines, several buildings and structures were damaged, including the historic Baguio Cathedral. The city's infrastructure, including roads and bridges, also suffered damage.

## Ilocos Sur

Ilocos Sur was also severely affected, with widespread destruction reported in the province's capital, Vigan. The province's historic town center, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, suffered significant damage, with several buildings and structures destroyed or damaged.

## Metro Manila

While Metro Manila was not directly affected by the earthquake, several buildings and structures in the capital region suffered damage. The Ninoy Aquino International Airport was temporarily closed due to damage to the terminal building.

## Elsewhere

Other provinces, including La Union, Pangasinan, and Nueva Ecija, also reported damage and casualties. The earthquake's impact was felt as far as the Bicol Region in the eastern Philippines.
